results.title: A Likely story! = Quelle histoire!
results.creator_credit: Koos Hillenaar, Kohill Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated refresher course on Canadian history for people who may be a little rusty on what happened in the centuries preceding Confederation. Cartoon animation gives life, substance and humor to the characters who have crossed the stage of Canadian history, from Columbus to Macdonald, treating them with a satirical wit that would be impossible in any learned treatise.

results.title: A Lecture on man
results.creator_credit: Richard Williams and Richard Williams Films
results.brief_description: Using live action clips, still photography and various animation techniques, Richard Williams illustrates a lecture given by Christopher Logue on the human situation. It is a satirical look at humans, their aspirations, and habits. The twin evils of patriotism and nationalism are exposed. (Awards: Mannheim; Annecy)

results.title: A la Decouverte du Monde (Ep.2)
results.brief_description:
This episode is dedicated to the great navigators: Colombus, Vespucci, Magellan, Jacques Cartier. It alos offers an overview of the settlement of the New World by mass migration and through the commerce of slaves. Other topics include: the exploration of the South seas by Cook, Bouguainville and Bligh ; the transfer of gold from the Americas to Spain on Galleons ; pirates.

Credits: Directors, writers, Daniel Costelle, Jean-Marc Leblon ; photography, Jean-Claude Larrieu, Roland Bernard ; technical adviser, Michel Mollat.

results.title: A la Decouverte de la Mer (Ep. 1)
results.brief_description:
This first episode focuses on the passionate relationship between man and the ocean. The sea was first of all an endless source of food for the coastal population. The series than moves on to profile the first bold sea voyagers: polynesian canoes, pharaonic pout sailing up and down the Nile as well as the Greek and roman sailors. Other topics include: Viking ship, the settlement of Greenland, the adoption of the latin (square) sail as well as the invention of the compass.

Credits: Directors, writers, Daniel Costelle, Jean-Marc Leblon ; photography, Jean-Claude Larrieu, Roland Bernard ; technical adviser, Michel Mollat.
Cast: Interviews with Dr. Alain Bombard, Jacques-Yves Cousteau, Jean Campistron.

results.title: A Kiwi in exile
results.brief_description: Short film made in 1958 by Graham Foster to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as a comic ‘ Day in the life’, the film features footage of Melbourne city and St Kilda and a constant wisecracking narrative from Foster. Of special interest is the segment on Foster’s working day at a Melbourne television station featuring the behind-the-scenes action. As television did not reach New Zealand until 1960, this short film was the easiest way to demonstrate to his family, exactly what he did in Australia.

results.title: A is for architecture [edited version]
results.creator_credit: Gerald Budner, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An edited version of “A is for Architecture”. A panorama of ancient cities, palaces and temples whose splendour awed the eyes of all mankind - recreated in colour by the skill of the animation artist. In documenting the changing concepts in architecture through the ages, the film moves from one tradition to another, illustrating how each reflects the sentiments and values of the time, from the massive temples of the Pharaohs to the soaring skyscrapers of today.

results.title: A is for architecture
results.creator_credit: Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A panorama of ancient cities, palaces and temples whose splendours awed the eyes of all mankind - recreated in colour by the skill of the animation artist. In documenting the changing concepts in architecture through the ages, the film moves from one tradition to another, illustrating how each reflects the sentiments and values of the time, from the massive temples of the Pharaohs to the soaring skyscrapers of today. Winner of eight film awards, including Rapallo Film Festival, Italy and Canadian Film Awards.

results.title: A Kid called Troy
results.creator_credit: Terry Carlyon, Michael J. Rivette and Carlyon and Rivette Pictures
results.brief_description: A profoundly moving and inspirational sequel to the critically acclaimed “Suzi’s Story”. It is the story of Vince and Troy Lovegrove, the father and son who survived Suzi when she died from AIDS in 1987. Troy carried the AIDS virus from birth. This is Troy’s story - the story of what it is to be seven, to love life as only a child can and yet to be a victim of AIDS.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry Carlyon, Michael J. Rivette and Carlyon and Rivette Pictures

results.title: A House on the prairie
results.creator_credit: Bob Lower, Ron Bashford, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The promise of riches in a new land lured many settlers to the West, but it was a harsh climate where shelter was the most urgent necessity. A House on the Prairie describes the legacy of these early days: environmentally unsuitable dwellings that now either devour money and fuel to remain functional, or slowly disintegrate in the sun, wind and frost. People today are beginning to recognize the importance of housing suitable to specific environments, and some of these new examples of western Canadian architecture are presented, with comments by designers, builders, and the people who live in the somewhat experimental dwellings.
